Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Clarifying the ingredients and significance of nonlocal versus local sediment transport on steepland hillslopes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hillslopes of varying steepness cover much of Earth's terrestrial surface, and may be entirely mantled with regolith or consist of bare bedrock surfaces, or involve mixtures of these conditions. Because of the central role of hillslope behavior in landscape dynamics, and because of the importance of soils and soil transport in critical zone processes that sustain much of life on Earth, the topic of sediment transport on hillslopes has a particularly rich legacy. Viewed at a human timescale, this topic is central to studies of erosion and erosion control in the agricultural and environmental sciences. Further, this topic is central in geomorphic studies focused on descriptions of transport that can be used in models of hillslope and landscape evolution. This project is aimed at clarifying the factors that contribute to "local" transport, where downslope sediment movement involves small particle motions controlled by local soil and land-surface conditions, versus "nonlocal" transport associated with soil slips, biotic disturbances (e.g., tree-throw), particle ravel following fire, etc., which can involve relatively rapid, long-distance sediment motions. The research will combine theoretical, experimental, and field-based work in the Oregon Coast Range and the Sierra Nevada Mountains to clarify rates of sediment transport and the effects of transport on changing steepland topography. The work is a collaborative research and education effort involving students and faculty from Vanderbilt University and the University of Oregon. It will provide teaching tools deriving from visualizations of experiments and numerical simulations, and it will provide data sets to the science community.

Recent work on hillslope sediment transport suggests the need to clarify the ingredients and implications of "nonlocal" versus "local" transport processes and associated formulations of the sediment flux, as expected hillslope behavior under these two conditions is quite different. However, the supporting theory has outpaced experimental and field-based observations needed to inform this theory. This project is aimed at closing that gap, as implications for understanding hillslope evolution are far-reaching. The project will: (1) combine experiments with scaling analyses to clarify ingredients of rarefied particle-surface interactions during their downslope motions, as these influence key processes of sediment disentrainment; (2) explore theoretical formulations of nonlocal transport for two-dimensional topography that is convergent-divergent in planform; (3) combine field observations with modeling work centered on hillslopes in the Oregon Coast Range and moraines in the Sierra Nevada Mountains that were selected to reveal ingredients of nonlocal transport behavior; and (4) formulate descriptions of nonlocal transport with appropriate space-time averaging to take into account the discontinuous (patchy, intermittent) nature of sediment motions on steepland hillslopes, as is necessary for treating the sediment flux as a time differentiable quantity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project is to understand the fundamental differences between sediment transport processes that move sediment down hillslopes. Our aim is to develop our theoretical understanding of these processes through a physics and statistical basis, to document field settings where these different processes are active, and to create experimental methods to test our hypotheses.

 

Sediment travels along hillslopes through a variety of geomorphic processes. Some of these processes move sediment short distances, and can be described as ?local? processes because they are controlled by the nearby conditions. Other processes relocate sediment both short and long distances, and are considered ?nonlocal? because they are more controlled by the statistical likelihood that the sediment will stop moving once it has begun motion.

 

Through this project, we further developed our theoretical understanding of the difference between local and nonlocal sediment transport processes by creating mathematical models that are based on the statistical mechanics of sediment transport. These models predict different shapes for hillslopes depending on what kind of processes are dominant. We documented field sites on glacial moraines where nonlocal sediment transport processes are active, measured the shape of these hillslopes, and collected rock and soil samples to quantify the rate of change these hillslopes have undergone. By comparing the measured shape to the predicted shapes generated by different models, we can state that local geomorphic processes cannot solely be responsible for the shape of these hills. The samples we collected show that the hills are changing in bursts of activity, which is also consistent with the predictions of nonlocal models. The results of this work provide the first field data to unequivocally demonstrate the action of nonlocal geomorphic processes, and identified key signatures that nonlocal processes create on a landscape. We also greatly enhanced our mathematical understanding of the physics and statistical probability that controls sediment transport, including natural tracer particles. We created an experimental hillslope to track colored pebbles as they move downhill to test hypotheses about the physics and statistical mechanics that influence sediment transport.

 

This project provided the basis of research training for one PhD student and three undergraduate students whose future careers likely will be centered on science and engineering. The PhD student completed his PhD and is currently a post-doctoral researcher at the University of Arizona. All three of the undergraduate students graduated with honors in Earth & Environmental Sciences by completing a senior thesis, and two of these thesis projects were based on the fieldwork and samples collected in this project. Two of the undergraduate students are currently graduate students, one at Purdue University and the other at the University of Southern California.
